clues.text: The "P" in I.P.A., an Iranian trade association, is for these green nuts, a big export for the country
The poet Firdawsi's epic chronicle of early Persian history is the "Shahnameh", or "Book of" these
Biblical personages traditionally said to be buried in Iran include this dream interpreter who had been exiled to Babylon
Also called Persian, this language is not related to Arabic, though it is written with the same characters
After puberty, all Iranian females are controversially required by law to wear one of these Arabic-named items in public

rounds.comments: (Ken: Each response will be two words.)

clues.text: A product's cost loses a letter & becomes a starchy staple
A member of the Corps loses a letter & becomes a New England state
Lose a letter from a word meaning a sorceress to become a preposition
A word for an abundant banquet loses a letter & becomes a compass direction
Lose a letter from a word meaning to declare allegiance & get a projection from a wall of rock
"Hey, Diddle, Diddle" sets up a possible sequel featuring the dish as it runs away with this
"Sing a Song of Sixpence" & include this somewhat imprecise amount of rye
"Old King Cole" doesn't need much to be merry--his pipe, his bowl & this musical act
"There was an old lady who swallowed a fly", but shockingly, this is next on the menu
The talkative "bells of St. Clement's" articulate this fruity pair
Bonds with a credit rating of BB+ or below are known as "high-yield" or, less flatteringly, this
Measuring the performance of 2,000 smaller companies, the Russell 2000 is a "small cap" one of these indicators
Term for investors trying to change a firm's direction; in a Feb. 2024 letter, Disney's board warned against that type of hedge fund
The "knock in" type of this is a contract that allows the holder to buy a stock once the price reaches a certain level
No investor wants to get this "call" in which a broker demands additional deposits be made in the same-named type of account
In a 1987 book Robert Ballard detailed his quest to find this at the bottom of the Atlantic
Shunmyo Masuno offers 100 ways to bring yourself happiness & calm in this form of Buddhism: "The Art of Simple Living"
Inspiring a Leonardo DiCaprio film, this Frank Abagnale memoir is subtitled "The True Story of a Real Fake"
In "The Demon of Unrest", this "Devil in the White City" author writes about the months between Lincoln's election & the start of the war
The epigraph to this classic 1962 book quotes Keats: "The sedge is wither'd from the lake, and no birds sing"
It's a tradition to leave pennies atop this assassin's tombstone at Green Mount Cemetery in Baltimore
In 1984 2 of her Sikh bodyguards shot her outside her home in New Delhi
In 1977 this assassin of Martin Luther King Jr. escaped from prison but was recaptured after 54 hours
Just days after stabbing Jean-Paul Marat through the heart, she lost her head on the guillotine
In 222 eccentric Roman emperor Elagabalus was assassinated by this group that was supposed to protect him
The name of this mountain that straddles the Switzerland & Italy border comes from German words for "meadow" & "peak"
Shrines devoted to Konohana-Sakuya Hime, a Shinto goddess, dot the trails of this 12,388-foot volcano
The American Alpine Institute says that Kahiltna Glacier on this mountain has "some of the widest temperature swings on the planet"
The Rongai Route passes by the Mawenzi Peak   before hitting Uhuru Peak on this mountain
Mount Corno in central Italy is the highest peak in this range
Serious poet W.H. Auden's anthology of light verse includes "the old woman who lived" here, but she buys a coffin for her "many children"
"'Mister!' he said with a sawdusty sneeze, 'I am"' this title character, "'I speak for the trees'"
Ogden Nash wrote that this Scottish poet, that "gifted souse, kindly immortalized the louse"
"We'll go where the chalk-white arrows go, for the children, they mark, and the children, they know, the place where" this "Ends"
This Victorian nonsense poet wrote, "the wandering dong through the forest goes!... the dong with a luminous nose!"
Too little of this is why home cooking is often bland compared with restaurant food--try the Maldon type & feel like a chef
From 1949 to 1957 the U.S. went through this climate event worse in some states than the one 20 years earlier
Hypoglycemia, too little blood sugar, is caused by having too much of this hormone
5-word phrase before "to Ride" for many sad too-little kids; it's the title of a documentary about R.I.'s famed Rocky Point Park
When the rebels ran out of ammo & fled, the Redcoats were victorious at this June 1775 Boston battle, but at a heavy cost
Once used for someone opposed to the slave trade, it can now mean an opposer of capital punishment
To remove the active stimulant from coffee or even tea
This noun can mean recognizing & valuing another's actions & qualities, or a rise in something's value over time
The California Highway Patrol says lane splitting by this person is legal
Named for colorful hosiery, it's an old-fashioned term for a female writer
It's the branch of biology that studies heredity & the passing on of characteristics
Similar to phototropism, it's the phenomenon of plants turning their leaves specifically towards the Sun
Deglutition is the act or process of doing this
Hormones, especially during puberty, cause these glands to produce more oil, which leads to clogged pores & acne
A peptide is a short chain of 2 to 50 of these; proteins are made up of 50 or more
Pearl Primus was often inspired by Black folk material, as in a dance set to this spiritual about Michael & his vessel
Choreographed by Agnes de Mille, this 1942 work with episodes like "Corral Nocturne" brought tap to ballet
Andy Blankenbuehler won Tony Awards for choreographing "Hamilton" & this earlier Lin-Manuel Miranda show
He had no dance training but created the memorable dance numbers in such films as "Dames" & "42nd Street"
"Helen of Troy" for American Ballet Theatre was the last work of this Russian-born "Firebird" choreographer

rounds.text: The only 2 Democrats to be elected president between James Buchanan in 1856 & FDR in 1932
